awd_titl_txt: Functionally Graded Carbon Nanotubes by Dynamic Control of Morphology during Chemical Vapor Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support basic research aimed at revealing the fundamental mechanisms underlying the process of manufacturing aligned carbon nanotubes for emerging applications of national interest.  Carbon nanotubes are tubes that are smaller than one ten-thousandth of a human hair and can be thought of as atom-thick sheets that are wrapped seamlessly into tubes. The superior chemical and physical properties of individual nanotubes, as well as the collective unique directionality of energy and mass transport through large populations of aligned carbon nanotubes underpin their potential in many critical technological areas.  The commercial production of carbon nanotubes exceeds several thousand tons per year and are used in products that rely on the random dispersion nanotubes of various lengths and diameters into a matrix to enhance the composite properties.  However, emerging applications such as high power-density devices, 3D nanoelectronics, nanoporous membranes, and structural materials require more precise control of the spatial variation of sizes, order and hierarchical morphology of aligned carbon nanotube ensembles.  This research looks to producing, through new understanding of their initial nucleation and subsequent growth, large arrays of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes which are all identical in width and length. These 'forests' of identical nanotubes have excellent mechanical properties and can be used in new application areas where the random length of the nanotubes would lead to poor performance.  Research in this project will contribute knowledge towards building the process-structure-property relationship necessary for pushing emerging applications of nanotubes closer to market, leading to enhancing the American economic competitiveness, while advancing university-level education of molecular-scale manufacturing. Public outreach will be facilitated by the continued development of YouTube channel explaining nanotechnology-related topics to a general audience.

The collective properties of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes (VACNTs) are dependent on the spatially varying morphology across their macroscopic forest-like structure. However, there is currently a lack of understanding of the mechanochemical factors governing the nucleation kinetics of large CNT populations, leading to an inability to control these variations in a repeatable fashion during the simultaneous growth of billions of CNTs. This project aims at filling this knowledge gap to enable precise control of spatially-engineered VACNTs grown by rapid thermal chemical vapor deposition (RT-CVD) and allow predicting their properties. This will be achieved by experimental growth of VACNTs under periodic growth conditions with in situ monitoring of height kinetics, combined with ex situ X-ray-based morphological characterization and electron microscopy, as well as stochastic modeling of the rates of catalytic activation and deactivation of CNTs nucleating from substrate-bound catalyst nanoparticles. Hence, the results generated from this project will enable predictably tuning CVD-grown CNTs in a process that is relevant to industrial CNT production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project generated new knowledge about the dynamic nature of carbon nanotube nucleation in large populations of billions of carbon nanotubes per centimeter squared in a custom-designed multizone chemical vapor deposition reactor with rapid thermal processing capability.  This new fundamental understanding was leveraged for creating vertically aligned CNT structures with controlled and spatially-varying structures and properties directly during growth by catalytic chemical vapor deposition (from engineered catalyst nanoparticle populations) based on controlled dynamic changes to process parameters. In addition, the growth yield was boosted by more than one order of magnitude and the run-to-run variability was reduced based on engineering not only the dynamic growth recipes but also the preconditioning of the reactor walls.

This project contribute to the realization of emerging applications of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), which require precise control on the order, hierarchical morphology, and placement of CNT ensembles, such as in the cases of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes (VACNTs), referred to as forests. Some of the applications of CNT forests are based on the utilization of a large number of CNTs in parallel, such as electrical interconnects, thermal interfaces, filtration membranes, chemical sensors, and reinforced composites.  Hence, this project creates the foundation to overcome major manufacturing challenges, which hinder breakthroughs in these applications.  Such challenges include (1) developing reproducible fabrication processes capable of controlling CNT diameter distribution, alignment and density, as well as ordering and placing them on substrates forming designed 2D/3D micron-/macroscale architectures; and (2) scalably producing tailored CNT structures (by design) for targeted applications, which rely on functionally graded morphologies.  Overcoming both challenges requires a comprehensive understanding of process-structure-property relationship governing the catalyst preparation step, during which substrate-bound metal (iron in this case) nanoparticles are formed on oxide support (aluminum oxide in this case), as well as the nucleation and growth steps of carbon nanotubes.  This project uniquely addresses these challenges by combining dynamic precision processing, in situ and ex situ characterization, and modeling the physicochemical atomic pathways involved in the fabrication process of VACNTs.


Last Modified: 01/06/2023
Modified by: Mostafa Bedewy
